awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Nanocomposite Structure Control via Nanoparticle Self-Assembly
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Robert J. Macfarlane of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry (MSN) program of the Division of Chemistry and the Solid State and Materials Chemistry (SSMC) program in the Division of Materials Research to develop nanocomposite building blocks composed of polymer grafted nanoparticles.  These building blocks are capable of assembling into ordered structures via molecular interactions, and may therefore be used to synthesize new composite materials with controllable physical properties.  The  project provides a new framework for controlling material structure across several length scales, generating materials by design for applications ranging from energy harvesting and storage to sensing technologies. The associated educational plans of the project focuses on the establishment of an outreach program to provide research experiences for community college educators and students.  The goals are to promote the involvement of students in cutting edge research techniques and to provide a pathway to future careers in STEM fields. 
 
In this project, nanocomposite building blocks (so called nanocomposite tectons, NCTs) are developed and used to manipulate the structure and composition of new materials at the atomic, nano, and macroscopic length scales simultaneously. NCTs consist of polymer grafted nanoparticles, where each polymer chain terminates in a functional group capable of supramolecular bonding.  Tuning of the bonding interactions of the NCTs allows for the directed assembly of nanoparticle superlattices.  The various design parameters which influence the self-assembly process (such as particle size, shape and composition, polymer composition and length, supramolecular group identity, solvent and matrix) are investigated.  Furthermore, the thermodynamic and kinetic parameters associated with NCT assembly are determined.  The goal is to assemble polymer-nanoparticle composites whose nanoscale structure induces unique optical phenomena such as photonic band gaps or coupled plasmon resonances.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

Nanocomposites are an important class of materials based on combining two disparate phases to achieve physical properties that cannot be found in any single phase material. Current syntheses often focus on chemical composition as the primary factor that determines these properties, but nanocomposite characteristics are also dependent upon the geometric arrangement of the phases and the chemical interface between them, requiring structure control at both the atomic and nanometer length scales. Moreover, in order to make useful materials for functional devices, nanocomposites must also be compatible with the processing technologies that mold them into the desired macroscale form. The major question that therefore arises is: how can nanocomposite material structure be controlled at the atomic, nano-, and macroscopic length scales simultaneously? This project focuses on the development of polymer grafted nanoparticles as building blocks, where the key innovation is the use of supramolecular bonding between polymer chains to dictate both particle-matrix and particle-particle interactions. The method established here is amenable to nanoparticles and polymers of different molecular compositions, and is also potentially compatible with multiple polymer processing techniques. The ultimate impact of this work is in enabling the next generation of nanocomposites with simultaneous multi-level structure control to precisely control material physical properties.

Intellectual Merit:

Nanocomposites derive their properties from the constituent particle and matrix compositions, the spatial positioning of the different phases, and the chemical interfaces between them. Self-assembly of building blocks that are inherently nanocomposites has provided unparalleled control over each of these design parameters, allowing for significantly more complex nanofiller organization than is provided by traditional methods based on mechanical mixing. Additionally, the ability to scale these nanoparticle superlattice materials to macroscopic quantities has resulted in novel processing strategies to generate fully three dimensional objects built entirely from self-assembly. As a result, we have developed the first method of making nanoparticle-superlattice-based materials that have complete structural control across seven orders of magnitude in length scale: molecular composition, nanoscale structuring, mesoscale organization, and macroscopic form. Finally, the combination of polymer brush coatings, colloidal building blocks, and supramolecular bonding interactions has enabled multiple fundamental discoveries in how systems of multivalent binding interactions act as a collective whole, enabling new research into the development of functional adhesives and structural materials. This award permitted the development of a new tool kit to explore the correlation between nanocomposite structure and physical characteristics. 

Broader Impact:

Nanocomposites consisting of organic and inorganic components present the best means of achieving materials with concurrent control over a range of desirable chemical, optical, mechanical, and other physical attributes for emerging applications in multiple areas. The methods developed here to independently control composition and nano- to macroscale ordering will allow for the synthesis of materials with designer properties that enable advances in sensing, display, optical, and energy storage technologies. In addition, this research program was used to train future chemists and materials scientists in interdisciplinary synthesis techniques, resulting in multiple successful transitions to high-profile careers in academia and industry. It also permitted the development of an outreach program to a local community college serving primarily underrepresented groups, allowing them to conduct cutting edge research with graduate student and postdoctoral scholar mentors. Finally, a new curriculum for this community college?s introductory chemistry students was developed based upon these research experiences, including advanced chemistry topics like polymer synthesis and characterization.


Last Modified: 04/30/2022
Modified by: Rob Macfarlane
